metadata.abstractText: Survival of KRAS mutant pancreatic cancer is critically dependent on reprogrammed metabolism including elevated macropinocytosis, autophagy, and lysosomal degradation of proteins. Lysosomal acidi at on is indispensable to protein catabolism, which makes it an exploitable metabolic target for KRAS mutant pancreatic cancer. Herein we investigated ultra-pH-sensitive micelles (UPSM) with pH-speci c bu ering of organelle pH and rapid drug release as a promising therapy against pancreatic cancer. UPSM undergo micelle unimer phase transition at their apparent p Ka, with dramatically increased bu er capacity in a narrow pH range (<0.3 pH). Cell studies including amino acid pro ling showed that UPSM inhibited lysosomal catabolism more e ciently than conventional lysosomotropic agents ( e.g., chloroquine) and induced cell apoptosis under starved condition. Moreover, pH-triggered rapid drug release from triptolide prodrugloaded UPSM (T-UPSM) signi cantly enhanced cytotoxicity over non-pH-sensitive micelles (T-NPSM). Importantly, TUPSM demonstrated superior safety and antitumor e cacy over triptolide and T-NPSM in KRAS mutant pancreatic cancer mouse models. Our ndings suggest that the ultra-pH-sensitive nanoparticles are a promising therapeutic platform to treat KRAS mutant pancreatic cancer through simultaneous lysosomal pH bu ering and rapid drug release.
